rev.comment: please discuss first before removing material from articles
rev.diff:
Line 5: Line 5:
Operating systems offer a number of services to application programs and users. Applications access these services through [[application programming interfaces]] (APIs) or [[system calls]]. By invoking these interfaces, the application can request a service from the operating system, pass parameters, and receive the results of the operation. Users may also interact with the operating system with some kind of software user interface (UI) like typing commands by using [[command line interface]] (CLI) or using a [[graphical user interface]] (GUI, commonly pronounced âgooeyâ). For hand-held and desktop computers, the user interface is generally considered part of the operating system. On large multi-user systems like Unix and Unix-like systems, the user interface is generally implemented as an application program that runs outside the operating system. (Whether the user interface should be included as part of the operating system is a point of contention.)
Operating systems offer a number of services to application programs and users. Applications access these services through [[application programming interfaces]] (APIs) or [[system calls]]. By invoking these interfaces, the application can request a service from the operating system, pass parameters, and receive the results of the operation. Users may also interact with the operating system with some kind of software user interface (UI) like typing commands by using [[command line interface]] (CLI) or using a [[graphical user interface]] (GUI, commonly pronounced âgooeyâ). For hand-held and desktop computers, the user interface is generally considered part of the operating system. On large multi-user systems like Unix and Unix-like systems, the user interface is generally implemented as an application program that runs outside the operating system. (Whether the user interface should be included as part of the operating system is a point of contention.)
â
+
[[Image:Ubuntu.png|thumb|[[Ubuntu]], a [[GNU/Linux]] based operating system]]
Common contemporary operating systems include [[Darwin operating system|Mac OS]], [[Windows NT|Windows]], [[Linux kernel|Linux]], [[BSD]] and [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]]. While servers generally run on [[Unix]] or [[Unix-like]] systems, embedded device markets are split amongst several operating systems.<ref>[http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070903-linux-marketshare-set-to-surpass-windows-98.html Linux market share set to surpass Win 98, OS X still ahead of Vista]</ref><ref>[http://www.linux-watch.com/news/NS5369154346.html Linux server market share keeps growing]</ref>
Common contemporary operating systems include [[Darwin operating system|Mac OS]], [[Windows NT|Windows]], [[Linux kernel|Linux]], [[BSD]] and [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]]. While servers generally run on [[Unix]] or [[Unix-like]] systems, embedded device markets are split amongst several operating systems.<ref>[http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070903-linux-marketshare-set-to-surpass-windows-98.html Linux market share set to surpass Win 98, OS X still ahead of Vista]</ref><ref>[http://www.linux-watch.com/news/NS5369154346.html Linux server market share keeps growing]</ref>
